title: Michael Dubke, Trump's communications director, quits
content:
The White House communications director , Michael Dubke , has resigned , in the first sign that a long-expected staff shakeup by the president has begun .
John McCain urges allies to stand by Trump 's US during 'troubled times ' Read more
Senior White House officials confirmed to ███ that Dubke handed in his resignation on 18 May , before Donald Trump left for his first overseas trip , a rocky nine-day tour through the Middle East and Europe that left key allies shaken .
Trump has been reported to be considering a shakeup , with the White House press secretary , Sean Spicer , believed likely to be moved . On Tuesday , White House aide Kellyanne Conway brushed off speculation that more personnel changes were coming .
“ In terms of , quote , ‘ staff shakeups ’ , I always read things that simply aren ’ t true , ” Conway said in an interview with Fox and Friends on Tuesday morning . “ I work here every day , it ’ s much more collaborative than people realize . We ’ re constantly being told by people who ’ ve never worked in the White House , let alone this White House , what ’ s going on here . ”
Conway , who has previously dismissed stories that have later proved to be true , added : “ I also would note , because many people again misreported this , that Sean Spicer is expected back at the podium today for an on-the-record briefing at 2pm . ”
According to a report in Axios , Trump is considering an overhaul to the White House communications strategy , which could include fewer on-camera briefings .
“ There will always be White House briefings , ” Conway said . But she added : “ Not every briefing has to be on camera . ”
In a statement , the White House chief of staff , Reince Priebus – himself the subject of reports of a possible move – thanked Dubke and suggested the former official would continue to be a vocal supporter of Trump ’ s agenda .
“ We appreciate Mike and are very grateful for his service to President Trump and our country , ” Priebus said . “ Mike tendered his resignation just before the president ’ s historic international trip and offered to remain onboard until a transition is concluded . Mike will assist with the transition and be a strong advocate for the President and the President ’ s policies moving forward . ”
Trump , meanwhile , apparently bypassing his communications team , fired off two tweets on Tuesday , dismissing the Russia investigation as “ fake news ” .
“ Russian officials must be laughing at the US & how a lame excuse for why the Dems lost the election has taken over the fake news , ” the president wrote .
Trump has repeatedly refused to accept the conclusion by US intelligence agencies that Moscow disrupted the 2016 presidential election by hacking Democratic emails . The FBI and at least three congressional committees and subcommittees are investigating Russian interference , and a special counsel was recently appointed to investigate whether Trump ’ s associates may have colluded with Russia during the campaign .
The tweet follows a report by the Washington Post that Jared Kushner , Trump ’ s son-in-law and senior adviser , sought a “ back channel ” to communicate secretly with the Kremlin . In a statement to the New York Times , Trump said he had “ total confidence ” in his son-in-law . On Tuesday , he retweeted a Fox News article headlined : “ Jared Kushner didn ’ t suggest Russian communications channel in meeting , source says . ”
At Tuesday ’ s press briefing at the White House , a somewhat irascible Spicer declined to confirm details , saying : “ Mr Kushner ’ s attorney has said Mr Kushner has volunteered to share with Congress what he knows about these meetings and he will do the same if he ’ s contacted in connection with any other inquiry . I ’ m not going to get into what the president did or did not discuss . ”
John Kelly , the homeland security secretary , appeared to defend Kushner ’ s actions over the weekend , arguing that any channel of communication is “ a good thing ” . Spicer seemed more reluctant to imply that such a channel existed , criticising assumptions based on unnamed sources , but reiterated a similar line of argument .
“ That being said , I think Secretary Kelly and [ national security adviser ] Gen McMaster have both discussed in general terms back channels are an appropriate part of diplomacy . ”
In a string of early morning tweets on Sunday , of which some were deleted and reposted for spelling errors , Trump said it was his opinion that “ many of the leaks coming out of the White House are fabricated lies made up by the # FakeNews media ” .
Spicer clashed angrily with reporters toward the end of Tuesday ’ s briefing . He said Trump was frustrated to see stories “ come out that are patently false , to see narratives that are wrong , to see ‘ fake news ’ . When you see stories that get perpetrated that are absolutely false , that are not based in fact , that is troubling and he ’ s rightly concerned . ”
Challenged to give an example of fake news , Spicer cited a tweet by a BBC journalist last Friday that claimed Trump had been rude by not using an earpiece to listen to the Italian prime minister at the G7 . He then became embroiled in a heated argument with reporters in the briefing room .
The spokesman said : “ I think there ’ s a lot of this stuff that ’ s gotten pushed out based on unnamed and unaccountable sources that is very troubling. ” The Fox News article that Trump had tweeted earlier in the day was itself based on an anonymous source .
Spicer was also asked about incidents of violence against reporters , including in Montana , when ███ ’ s Ben Jacobs was assaulted by Republican congressman-elect Greg Gianforte . He said simply : “ We ’ ll take a stance against violence against any individual . ”
Trump also resurfaced his criticism of Germany on Tuesday , admonishing the US ally for what he has repeatedly characterized as a failure to “ pay their fair share ” to the Nato alliance and the country ’ s military .
The rebuke may have been prompted by the suggestion by the German chancellor , Angela Merkel , that her country can no longer completely rely on its longstanding British and US allies .
Trump tweeted : “ We have a MASSIVE trade deficit with Germany , plus they pay FAR LESS than they should on NATO & military . Very bad for U.S . This will change . ”
Spicer insisted that increased burden sharing among Nato allies was a positive step . “ I think the relationship that the president has had with Merkel he would describe as fairly unbelievable . They get along very well . He has a lot of respect for her . They continue to grow the bond that they had during their talks in the G7 and he views not just Germany but the rest of Europe as an important American ally . ”

The White House communications director, Michael Dubke, has resigned, in the first sign that a long-expected staff shakeup by the president has begun.

John McCain urges allies to stand by Trump's US during 'troubled times' Read more

Senior White House officials confirmed to the Guardian that Dubke handed in his resignation on 18 May, before Donald Trump left for his first overseas trip, a rocky nine-day tour through the Middle East and Europe that left key allies shaken.

Trump has been reported to be considering a shakeup, with the White House press secretary, Sean Spicer, believed likely to be moved. On Tuesday, White House aide Kellyanne Conway brushed off speculation that more personnel changes were coming.

“In terms of, quote, ‘staff shakeups’, I always read things that simply aren’t true,” Conway said in an interview with Fox and Friends on Tuesday morning. “I work here every day, it’s much more collaborative than people realize. We’re constantly being told by people who’ve never worked in the White House, let alone this White House, what’s going on here.”

Conway, who has previously dismissed stories that have later proved to be true, added: “I also would note, because many people again misreported this, that Sean Spicer is expected back at the podium today for an on-the-record briefing at 2pm.”

According to a report in Axios, Trump is considering an overhaul to the White House communications strategy, which could include fewer on-camera briefings.

“There will always be White House briefings,” Conway said. But she added: “Not every briefing has to be on camera.”

In a statement, the White House chief of staff, Reince Priebus – himself the subject of reports of a possible move – thanked Dubke and suggested the former official would continue to be a vocal supporter of Trump’s agenda.

“We appreciate Mike and are very grateful for his service to President Trump and our country,” Priebus said. “Mike tendered his resignation just before the president’s historic international trip and offered to remain onboard until a transition is concluded. Mike will assist with the transition and be a strong advocate for the President and the President’s policies moving forward.”

Trump, meanwhile, apparently bypassing his communications team, fired off two tweets on Tuesday, dismissing the Russia investigation as “fake news”.



“Russian officials must be laughing at the US & how a lame excuse for why the Dems lost the election has taken over the fake news,” the president wrote.

Facebook Twitter Pinterest Michael Dubke, right, during a press conference in April. Photograph: Shawn Thew/EPA

Trump has repeatedly refused to accept the conclusion by US intelligence agencies that Moscow disrupted the 2016 presidential election by hacking Democratic emails. The FBI and at least three congressional committees and subcommittees are investigating Russian interference, and a special counsel was recently appointed to investigate whether Trump’s associates may have colluded with Russia during the campaign.

The tweet follows a report by the Washington Post that Jared Kushner, Trump’s son-in-law and senior adviser, sought a “back channel” to communicate secretly with the Kremlin. In a statement to the New York Times, Trump said he had “total confidence” in his son-in-law. On Tuesday, he retweeted a Fox News article headlined: “Jared Kushner didn’t suggest Russian communications channel in meeting, source says.”

At Tuesday’s press briefing at the White House, a somewhat irascible Spicer declined to confirm details, saying: “Mr Kushner’s attorney has said Mr Kushner has volunteered to share with Congress what he knows about these meetings and he will do the same if he’s contacted in connection with any other inquiry. I’m not going to get into what the president did or did not discuss.”

John Kelly, the homeland security secretary, appeared to defend Kushner’s actions over the weekend, arguing that any channel of communication is “a good thing”. Spicer seemed more reluctant to imply that such a channel existed, criticising assumptions based on unnamed sources, but reiterated a similar line of argument.

“That being said, I think Secretary Kelly and [national security adviser] Gen McMaster have both discussed in general terms back channels are an appropriate part of diplomacy.”

In a string of early morning tweets on Sunday, of which some were deleted and reposted for spelling errors, Trump said it was his opinion that “many of the leaks coming out of the White House are fabricated lies made up by the #FakeNews media”.

Spicer clashed angrily with reporters toward the end of Tuesday’s briefing. He said Trump was frustrated to see stories “come out that are patently false, to see narratives that are wrong, to see ‘fake news’. When you see stories that get perpetrated that are absolutely false, that are not based in fact, that is troubling and he’s rightly concerned.”

Challenged to give an example of fake news, Spicer cited a tweet by a BBC journalist last Friday that claimed Trump had been rude by not using an earpiece to listen to the Italian prime minister at the G7. He then became embroiled in a heated argument with reporters in the briefing room.

The spokesman said: “I think there’s a lot of this stuff that’s gotten pushed out based on unnamed and unaccountable sources that is very troubling.” The Fox News article that Trump had tweeted earlier in the day was itself based on an anonymous source.

Spicer was also asked about incidents of violence against reporters, including in Montana, when the Guardian’s Ben Jacobs was assaulted by Republican congressman-elect Greg Gianforte. He said simply: “We’ll take a stance against violence against any individual.”

Trump also resurfaced his criticism of Germany on Tuesday, admonishing the US ally for what he has repeatedly characterized as a failure to “pay their fair share” to the Nato alliance and the country’s military.

The rebuke may have been prompted by the suggestion by the German chancellor, Angela Merkel, that her country can no longer completely rely on its longstanding British and US allies.

Trump tweeted: “We have a MASSIVE trade deficit with Germany, plus they pay FAR LESS than they should on NATO & military. Very bad for U.S. This will change.”

Spicer insisted that increased burden sharing among Nato allies was a positive step. “I think the relationship that the president has had with Merkel he would describe as fairly unbelievable. They get along very well. He has a lot of respect for her. They continue to grow the bond that they had during their talks in the G7 and he views not just Germany but the rest of Europe as an important American ally.”
